claim: Fortune cookies originated in California, not China, as commonly believed.

supporting.text: Historical records indicate that fortune cookies were first mass-produced in California by Japanese immigrants in the early 20th century.

attacks.text: Historical records indicate that fortune cookies were first mass-produced in California by Japanese immigrants in the early 20th century.
Some historians argue that similar cookies with embedded messages existed in China long before their appearance in California, suggesting a Chinese origin.
The Chinese versions were not mass-produced and lacked the standardized form and distribution of the California fortune cookies, making them distinct.
The Japanese immigrants in California may have been inspired by Chinese traditions, implying the cookies' cultural roots are still Chinese.
Cultural inspiration does not equate to origin; the modern fortune cookie as we know it was developed and popularized independently in California.

supporting.text: Fortune cookies are not a traditional Chinese dessert and have no documented history in Chinese cuisine before their appearance in the United States.

attacks.text: Fortune cookies are not a traditional Chinese dessert and have no documented history in Chinese cuisine before their appearance in the United States.
Some historians suggest that fortune cookies may have been inspired by similar Japanese crackers, which were brought to California by Japanese immigrants.
The Japanese crackers were distinct in form and content, lacking the paper fortunes that define modern fortune cookies.
Early 20th-century Chinese immigrants in California adapted the concept, making it distinctively American-Chinese.
There is no direct evidence linking early Chinese-American bakers to the invention of fortune cookies, leaving the origin unclear.

supporting.text: The modern fortune cookie design and production process were developed by American companies in California, not in China.

attacks.text: The modern fortune cookie design and production process were developed by American companies in California, not in China.
The concept of inserting messages into baked goods has historical roots in China, dating back to the 13th century.
While the concept may have Chinese origins, the specific design and mass-production method of fortune cookies are distinctly American innovations.
Early 20th-century Japanese immigrants in California also produced similar cookies, suggesting the idea was not exclusively American.
The Japanese version was different in shape and content, and the modern fortune cookie was standardized by American manufacturers.

supporting.text: Chinese culinary experts and historians widely acknowledge that fortune cookies are an American invention, not a Chinese one.

attacks.text: Chinese culinary experts and historians widely acknowledge that fortune cookies are an American invention, not a Chinese one.
Some Chinese-American communities claim that fortune cookies have roots in 19th-century Chinese bakeries, predating their popularity in California.
Historical records from these Chinese bakeries do not mention fortune cookies, suggesting the claim is a later reinterpretation.
Early 20th-century Japanese immigrants in California also made similar cookies, complicating the origin story.
Japanese versions lacked written fortunes, distinguishing them from the modern fortune cookie design popularized in America.

supporting.text: The association of fortune cookies with Chinese restaurants in the U.S. is a result of marketing and cultural adaptation, not origin.

attacks.text: The association of fortune cookies with Chinese restaurants in the U.S. is a result of marketing and cultural adaptation, not origin.
Fortune cookies closely resemble traditional Chinese mooncakes and other baked goods, suggesting a Chinese origin.
Mooncakes and fortune cookies differ significantly in ingredients, preparation, and cultural significance, weakening the resemblance argument.
Early 20th-century records show fortune cookies being produced by Japanese immigrants in California, not Chinese immigrants.
Japanese immigrants may have adapted the concept from Chinese culinary traditions, making the origin more ambiguous.
